title: 112_hr6292
content: The Act may be cited as the "Justice for Imprisoned Americans Overseas Act of 2012" or the "Jacob's Law of 2012." The "Justice for Imprisoned Americans Overseas Act of 2012" requires the President to demand the release of unjustly detained citizens and Secretary of State Hillary Clinton emphasized the responsibility to protect U.S. citizens abroad. Some US citizens imprisoned abroad face violations of due process and human rights by foreign officials. Jacob Ostreicher, held in Bolivia since 2011, is enduring severe violations. Congress believes officials responsible for such violations should not be allowed to travel to the US. Some US citizens imprisoned abroad face violations of due process and human rights by foreign officials, like Jacob Ostreicher in Bolivia since 2011. Congress believes officials responsible for such violations should not be allowed to travel to the US, while US citizens unjustly languish in their prisons. SEC. 3. DENIAL OF ENTRY INTO THE UNITED STATES OF CERTAIN FOREIGN GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS. The Secretary of State may not issue visas or allow entry to the US for foreign government officials identified in certain circumstances. If a US citizen dies in the custody of a foreign government, officials related to the case and their family members are permanently banned from entering the US. The Secretary of State must report to Congress every 180 days for five years on US citizens imprisoned abroad facing human rights violations. The report must identify the violations and the government officials possibly responsible. The Secretary of State must report every 180 days to Congress on US citizens imprisoned abroad facing human rights violations, identifying the responsible government officials and their immediate family members denied entry to the United States. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The term "immediate family members" includes a spouse, children, parents, siblings, and fiance or fiancee.
